data.title: Algonquin Provincial Park: Hello from… – Old – New to Me – I See Red
data.meta_description: Algonquin totem pole and memorial to childrens’ remains uncovered in mass graves in some of Canada’s notorious northern residential schools for Indigenous people. All photo ©Aaron Paulson (Working on…
data.text:
Hello from

Algonquin Provincial Park, Ontario

Algonquin totem pole and memorial to childrens’ remains uncovered in mass graves in some of Canada’s notorious northern residential schools for Indigenous people. All photo ©Aaron Paulson

(Working on my iPad in the waiting lounge at Pearson International Airport. Please be kind with any typos/formatting issues)

Algonquin Provincial Park, in south-central Ontario, is one of the largest, most accessible, and certainly most famous multi-purpose provincial parks in Canada.

I have made many trips to the park, starting from day trips with my parents when I was still a toddler to week-long canoe expeditions into the Park’s wild and remote interior.

This summer, my wife R. and I, along with a few experienced friends, gently introduced a couple of our less experienced friends to the Park by way of a long weekend at a summer home rental just outside the Park boundaries.

Long story short, we have just returned to Toronto as I write this, missing by just a couple of weeks the summer wildfires that had been burning earlier in June and clouding cities as…
